Wage supplements are awarded to professionals for length of service and who have a certification or higher education in early-childhood-related studies. The program aims to augment low wages as well as decrease teacher turnover, helping children maintain a stable relationship with their caregiver. This Wage Supplement program focused on those staff at Early Learning Programs who have a CDA, Associates, Bachelors or Masters degree for a college or university. Outcome: A survey was given to Jeanette Watson recipients 4 months after they received their award letter. At that time, 96 of the 101 recipients reported they were still employed at the same program. A rate of 95%, well above the industry average. A follow up survey will be sent to all programs 6 months after recipients received their wage supplement payment, asking which of those staff are still employed at the program.

Program evaluation dates have been schedule. Between 01/01/24-03/31/24, out of 33 students 48% of children were experiencing more than 7.8+ conversational turns per hour. 100% of children who started out experiencing less talk than the national median of 15 turns per hour had an average increase of +11.5 turns per hour. 56% of children who started out experiencing less talk than their peers in the same classroom (in the bottom third) had an average increase of +6.9 turns per hour. 2 programs and 3 classrooms served.
4 | 2 | North Central Texas | Evaluation & Assessment | WSNCT provided CLASS assessments for 72 classrooms and 2 reliably double-coded classrooms from 12 early learning programs in the Fall and the Spring. The assessments were completed by contracted CLASS certified observers. | Ongoing | 12 | Fall 2023 Class scores were received and distributed. 72 classrooms were observed, and 2 were double coded. Within the 72 classrooms observed, there were 16 infants, 25 toddlers, and 29 preschool classrooms observed.  The infant rooms scored an average of 4.82/7 in their only domain, Responsive Caregiving. The toddler classrooms averaged 5.64/7 in Emotional & Behavior Support and 3.62/7 in Engaged Support for Learning. PreK classrooms scored an average of 5.66/7 in Emotional Support, 5.12/7 in Classroom organization, and 2.81/7 in Instructional Support. This is 100% of the board's goal of 12 programs served.

4 | 3 | North Central Texas | Evaluation & Assessment | WSNCT offered LENA Grow in 27 early learning classrooms within 2 programs. LENA Grow is an evaluation tool that tracks and measures teacher-child interactions over 11 weeks with guided coaching sessions. WSNCT provided devices to early learning programs within our Texas Rising Star early learning programs to support Category 2: Teacher-Child Interactions in the Texas Rising Star assessment tool. | Ongoing | 2 | 2 early learning programs have participated in the LENA Grow evaluation tool to track teacher child interactions. Program evaluation dates have been schedule. Between 04/01/24-06/30/24, out of 88 students 10% of children were experiencing more than 1.8+ conversational turns per hour. 40% Children who started out experiencing less talk than the national median of 15 turns per hour had an average increase of +3.0 turns per hour. 67% of Children who started out experiencing less talk than their peers in the same classroom (in the bottom third) had an average increase of +5.6 turns per hour. 12 teachers, 2 programs, and 7 classrooms served. This activity reached 7/27 classrooms which is 26% of the board's goal of 27 classrooms.
4 | 3 | North Central Texas | Evaluation & Assessment | WSNCT provided CLASS assessments for 72 classrooms and 2 reliably double-coded classrooms from 12 early learning programs in the Fall and the Spring. CLASS gives Early Childhood Specialists the tools, data, and framework to objectively and accurately support teacher-child interactions. These assessments were completed by contracted CLASS certified observers. | Ongoing | 11 | 11 early learning programs with 63 classrooms (one double coded) served which completed 92% of the board's estimated reach of 12 participants. Spring 2024 Class scores were received and distributed. The results are as follows for the 2023-2024 school year pertaining to the updated information received from the spring scores. Within the 62 classrooms that have been observed so far, with 1 school still pending. There were 14 infant, 23 toddler and 25 preschool classrooms observed. The infant rooms scored an average of 4.99/7 in fall and 5.12/7 in spring. This shows an increase of 13% improvement in their only domain of Overall Responsive Caregiving. The toddler classrooms have a total of 2 domains. The toddler rooms scored an average of 5.47/7 in fall and 5.60/7 in spring. This shows an increase of 13% in the domain of Overall Emotional & Behavior Support. The toddler room also scored an average of 3.59/7 in the fall and 3.54/7 in the spring. This shows a decrease of 4% in the domain Overall Engaged Support for Learning. The PreK classrooms have a total of 3 domains. The PreK classrooms score an average of 5.75/7 in fall and 5.79/7 in spring. This shows an increase of 3% in the domain of Overall Emotional Support. PreK also scored an average of 5.16/7 in the fall and 5.07/7 in the spring. This shows a decrease of 9% in the domain of Overall Classroom Organization. PreK’s final class scores an average of 2.99/7 in the fall and 2.72/7 in the spring. This shows a decrease of 27% in the domain of Overall Instructional Support.

4 | 4 | North Central Texas | Evaluation & Assessment | As a part of the strategic plan for WSNCT quality child care, WSNCT offered LENA Grow in 5 early learning programs (supporting 27 classrooms). LENA Grow is an evaluation tool that tracks and measures teacher-child interactions over 11 weeks with guided coaching sessions. WSNCT provided devices to these Texas Rising Star early learning programs to support Category 2: Teacher-Child Interactions in the Texas Rising Star assessment tool. | Ongoing | 5 | 9 early learning classrooms in 5 early learning programs have participated in the LENA Grow evaluation tool to track teacher child interactions. 22 | 4 | Coastal Bend | Infant & Toddler | Early Literacy Initiative for Infants.  WFSCB purchased/distributed 130 sets of "soft" cloth and "board" books in infant classrooms at 79 Texas Rising Star Entry Level designated child care centers and home providers during the fourth quarter. The titles of these books were "Pets", "Animals", "Numbers", "Shapes", "Vehicles", and "Baby's First Words". The books will be used by the infants during "tummy" time which will enable them to develop their sensory skills and "hand-eye" coordination. | Completed | 79 | WFSCB achieved 48% of its goal to place sets of "soft" and "board" books in all (164 child care providers and home providers) of the infant classrooms/home providers.  We will survey these child care providers during the first quarter of BCY2025 to determine how the infants in these classrooms are progressing towards these developmental milestones.  While we feel that assisting infants in developing their sensory skills and "hand-eye" coordination are very important developmental milestones, WFSCB will not continue this initiative in BCY2025 due to less than 50% of the child care providers' responding to our survey for interest in this initiative.
